question: What is the main aim to perform an autopsy?

answers.option: To look for signs of life
To identify the cause of death
To look for any possible injuries

question: 25-year-old sexually active woman complaint of greenish-yellow vaginal discharge. Culture shows Gram-negative diplococci. What is the causative agent?

Other symptoms were nausea, vomiting, increased sensitivity to light, and confusion. Cerebrospinal fluid was sent to the laboratory for routine culture and a detailed report. Microscopic examination showed diplococci organisms. Growth revealed grey colonies, which were catalase negative. Which of the following bacteria is most probably causing infection?

A 25-year-old man got into a road traffic accident. He has abrasions all over his legs because of drag he experienced during the accident. His immunization history is unclear. Which form of immunity should be provided immediately?

answers.option: Active immunity with live attenuated bacteria

question: A 25-year-old woman has had several severe episodes of pneumonia in the past 5 months. She has not had frequent or unusual infections before the onset of this pneumonia. Which of the following is the most likely immunodeficiency that predisposes her to these infections?

answers.option: Mutation in the gene that encodes the C3a portion of the complement
Defect in cytotoxic T cells function

answers.option: A mix of live and killed vaccines

question: A 45-year-old female developed a fever with burning micturition. She was diagnosed with having urinary tract infection. The growth on the blood agar showed swarming organisms. Other chemical tests were performed. Gram-negative, non-spore-forming, oxidase-negative, non-lactose fermenting, H₂S-producing rod-shaped bacteria were isolated. Infection in the urinary tract may occur with indwelling catheters. Which organism is isolated in this patient?

A 45-year-old male patient presented with post-operative surgical site infection after emergency laparotomy. Sample of pus collected in a sterile syringe and sent to lab for routine culture and sensitivity. Gram stain revealed Gram positive cocci in clusters with numerous pus cells. After 24 hours beta hemolytic colonies grew on sheep blood agar plate, which was catalase and coagulase positive. What is the most likely causative etiologic agent?

The sample was pus collected in a sterile syringe and sent to the laboratory for routine culture and sensitivity. Gram-stain revealed Gram-positive cocci in clusters with numerous pus cells. After 24 hours, beta-hemolytic colonies grew on the sheep blood agar plate, which was coagulase and catalase positive. What is the most likely causative agent?
